title: Five People Denied US Visas for Campaigning Against Online Hate
summary: Five people, including two from the UK, were denied visas to enter the United States. The US government said they were trying to force American social media companies to remove content they don't like. The people work for groups that fight online hate and false information. European leaders, like the French president, criticized this decision, calling it intimidation. The US argued it was protecting free speech from foreign pressure. This story shows a disagreement about how to handle harmful content online between different countries.

background_read: This story is about how countries sometimes disagree on how to handle problems on the internet, like hate speech or false information. In the United States, there is a strong belief in free speech, which means people can say almost anything without government interference. In Europe, some groups and laws try to make social media companies remove harmful content to protect people. When the US denied visas to campaigners from Europe, it sparked a debate about whether foreign groups should influence American companies. This shows the challenges of global cooperation on internet issues.
Article_Structure: WHO: Two British campaigners, Imran Ahmed and Clare Melford, and three others from France and Germany.
WHAT: They were denied US visas for trying to make American social media remove content they oppose.
WHERE: This happened between the United States and European countries.
WHY: The US says it's protecting free speech, while Europe sees it as intimidation against fighting online hate.

perspectives.description: The US believes it is defending free speech by stopping foreign groups from pressuring American companies to censor content.
European leaders and campaigners see the visa denials as an attack on efforts to combat online disinformation and hate speech.
